0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Tetanus diphtheria vaccination: (Decavac(R)) primary immunization is a 3-dose series, each dose is 0.5 mL IM; administer dose 1 and 2 at least 4 weeks apart and administer dose 3 at least 6 months after second injection; routine booster every 10 years thereafter
  • Tetanus diphtheria vaccination: (Tenivac(R)) primary immunization is a 3-dose series, each dose is 0.5 mL IM; administer first and second dose 2 months apart and administer third dose 6 to 8 months after second injection; routine booster every 10 years thereafter

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Tetanus diphtheria vaccination: (6 weeks up to 7 years; pediatric formulation) primary immunization is a 5-dose series, each dose is 0.5 mL IM; recommended ages for administration are 2, 4, 6, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years
  • Tetanus diphtheria vaccination: (7 years or older; Tenivac(R)) primary immunization is a 3-dose series, each dose is 0.5 mL IM; administer first and second dose 2 months apart and administer third dose 6 to 8 months after second injection; routine booster at age 11 to 12 years and every 10 years thereafter
  • Tetanus diphtheria vaccination: (7 years or older; Decavac(R)) primary immunization is a 3 dose series, each dose is 0.5 mL IM; administer dose 1 and 2 at least 4 weeks apart and administer dose 3 at least 6 months after second injection; routine booster at age 11 to 12 years and every 10 years thereafter

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe allergic reaction (eg, anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of any diphtheria toxoid- or tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine or to any component of the vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Immunologic:
  • -- avoid administering tetanus-toxoid containing vaccines more frequently than every 10 years in patients with a past history of arthus type hypersensitivity reactions to prior tetanus toxoid-containing vaccin
  • -- acute hypersensitivity or anaphylactic reaction may occur; ensure adequate treatment is available including epinephrine (1:1000) solution
  • -- tip caps of the prefilled syringes contain natural rubber latex; allergic reaction may occur in latex-sensitive individuals
  • -- desired immune response may not be achieved in immunocompromised patients, including those receiving immunosuppressive therapy
  • Neurologic:
  • --brachial neuritis and Guillain-Barre syndrome have been associated with tetanus toxoid administration
  • -- if Guillain-Barre has occurred within 6 weeks of administering prior tetanus-toxoid containing vaccines, weigh the potential risk versus benefit prior to vaccination with any other tetanus-toxoid containing vaccines

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (pediatrics, 19.7% to 25.6%; adults, 15.8% to 21.6%), Injection site pain (pediatric, 71% to 80.1%; adult, 29.4% to 74.9%), Swelling at injection site (12.1% to 18.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (10.2% to 11.3%), Nausea (pediatric, 12.3%; adult, 7.9%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Generalized acute body pains, Inflamed joint (7% to 11.7%), Muscle weakness (pediatric, 32.3%; adult, 4.9% to 17.4%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (pediatric, 23% to 40.4%; adult, 10.8% to 34.1%)
  • Other:Fatigue (20.7 to 27.3%), Malaise (8.8% to 17%), Shivering (pediatric, 12.6%; adult, 6.6%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction, Hypersensitivity reaction, arthus type
  • Neurologic:Brachial neuritis, Guillain-Barr syndrome, Seizure

sub.title: Synonyms
sub.mono:
• Diphtheria and Tetanus Toxoids
  • Td - Tetanus and Diphtheria Toxoids
  • DT - Diphtheria and Tetanus Toxoids

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Diphtheria toxoid component helps reduce the risk of developing diphtheria and protects immunized persons for at least 10 years. The vaccine also enables vaccine recipients to develop only a mild form of the disease in case they do develop diphtheria. It induces the development of neutralizing antibodies to diphtheria toxin.
  • Tetanus toxoid component protects adequately immunized persons against tetanus for at least 10 years. The toxoid stimulates the development of neutralizing antibodies to tetanus toxin.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intramuscular
  • for IM use only; do not administer IV or SUBQ
  • shake well prior to use; discard syringe/vial if vaccine cannot be resuspended
  • do not remove the rubber stopper or metal seal holding it in place
  • (6 weeks up to 7 years) preferred injection sight is the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh or the deltoid; do not inject into gluteal area or areas containing a major nerve trunk
  • (7 years or older) preferred injection site is the deltoid; do not inject into gluteal area or areas containing a major nerve trunk
  • use a separate syringe and injection site when given concurrently with tetanus immune globulin

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: No specific monitoring has been determined.

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    Intramuscular Suspension: (Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed - Tetanus Toxoid) 2 Lf U/0.5 ML-2 Lf U/0.5 ML, 2 Lf U/0.5 ML-5 Lf U/0.5 ML, 25 Lf U/0.5 ML-5 Lf U/0.5 ML
  • Tenivac
    Intramuscular Suspension: (Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed - Tetanus Toxoid) 2 Lf U/0.5 ML-5 Lf U/0.5 ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report latex sensitivity prior to administration, as syringe contains latex.
  • Tell patient that vaccine may not provide complete protection against tetanus or diphtheria, particularly in the elderly (aged 65 or older).
  • Advise patient and caregivers on importance of completing the primary immunization series or receiving booster doses.
  • Direct patient or caregiver to report any suspected adverse reactions.
  • Side effects may include pain, headache, erythema or swelling at the injection site, malaise, muscle weakness, body aches, fatigue, or diarrhea.
